awd_titl_txt: Geometric Flows and Canonical Kahler Metrics
awd_abstract_narration:
Award: DMS 1710500, Principal Investigator: Bin Guo

The Einstein equations from gravitational theory have a geometric interpretation that picks out a preferred metric to determine lengths and angles on a space.  The determination of conditions for solvability of those equations has seen recent progress and continues to pose important open problems in geometry. The projects to be carried out include approaches to those problems through geometric flows that deform the metric on a space in a direction that might lead to a canonical metric, or, alternatively, might develop a singularity that blocks progress toward such a metric.

Some of these projects will study the formation of long-time and short-time singularities from Kaehler-Ricci flow which are closely related to the analytic minimal model program proposed by Song and Tian. The conical Kaehler-Einstein equations have been very successful for Fano manifolds, and these projects will investigate the existence and properties of conical canonical Kaehler metrics in algebraic varieties and explore their applications in solving open problems in algebraic geometry.  Another line of work will study coupled systems of parabolic type which originated from general relativity in physics. The solutions to the coupled systems will yield Einstein vacuum metrics and shed light on the structure of the underlying space.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
Bin Guo has completed the funded research under the support of NSF grants DMS-1710500 and DMS-1945869: ``Geometric Flows and Canonical Kahler Metrics''. During his funding period, Bin has made big progress in the analytic minimal model program laid out by Song and Tian, geometric regularity of complex Monge-Ampere equations and various geometric PDEs and other coupled systems.

 

As the Principal Investigator (PI), Bin has achieved the goal of research and published his research papers in peer-reviewed journals. Through the collaboration with other senior researchers and graduate students, Bin verifies the Gromov-Hausdorff convergence of the short-time Kahler-Ricci flow on a fiberation map given by a single blowup, and establishes the Gromov-Hausdorff convergence of Kahler-Ricci flow on Kahler surfaces of general type. Joint with Song, he confirms a long-standing conjecture on the uniqueness of blowup limit on certain Fano ruled manifolds with rotational symmetry. Together with Phong-Sturm, he provides a simplified and uniform proof of Kahler-Ricci flow on Fano manifolds admitting canonical metrics, and he verifies a long-standing question on the existence of Kahler-Einstein metrics on Fano manifolds in terms of the lower bound of certain eigenvalue of a Cauchy-Riemann operator. These achievements strengthen the effectiveness of analytic minimal model program and canonical Kahler metrics in complex differential geometry.

 

Bin has accomplished his intention to help graduate students and promote interdisciplinary corporations between different fields. Three of his published works were joint with graduate students. In the collaborations with these young and promising researchers, Bin shows the pseudo-locaity theorem for a coupled Ricci flow which is an important tool in understanding the singularity formation of this flow, find a deep relation between analytic bound on Kahler potentials with the geometric bound on diameters and Ricci curvature, and a degeneration of a family of complete Calabi-Yau metrics with cone-like ends. Joint with Fei-Phong, Bin discovers new solutions to the 11D-supergravity equations and introduces parabolic equations to solve these interesting equations from physics. This sheds new light on the applications of PDE theory in theoretic physics.

 

The PI has traveled to many universities and institutions in the United States, Germany, China and Canada, and he has given seminar or workshop talks and attended conferences on geometry and analysis, to disseminate his research works to colleagues. He co-organized the department colloquium at Rutgers University - Newark, and invited both the established and fresh researchers in various fields like geometry, analysis, topology and number theory to share their frontiers research works. This attracted many graduate students and provided them an opportunity to understand the modern development of different fields in mathematics.

 

In sum, Bin has accomplished the main goal of the funded program, in writing research papers, promoting young researchers and interdisciplinary corporations, and enhancing more people to the field of mathematics.

 


Last Modified: 10/29/2021
Modified by: Bin Guo
